content.definition: A class of oral anticoagulants that directly inhibit specific clotting factors (thrombin or Factor Xa) without requiring antithrombin as a cofactor. DOACs have largely replaced warfarin for many indications due to predictable pharmacokinetics, no routine monitoring, and fewer drug/food interactions.

direct_thrombin_inhibitor.name: Dabigatran (Pradaxa)
direct_thrombin_inhibitor.storage: Sensitive to humidity - keep in original container

reversal_agents.factor_xa_inhibitors: Andexanet alfa (Andexxa) - recombinant Factor Xa decoy

perioperative_management.minor_procedure: Usually hold 24-48 hours based on renal function
perioperative_management.high_bleeding_risk: Consider longer hold, reversal agent available

renal_dosing.apixaban: Safest in CKD; reduce dose if 2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, Cr ≥1.5
renal_dosing.dabigatran: Avoid if CrCl <30; reduce dose CrCl 30-50

learning_objectives: Know the DOAC classes and individual agents
clinical_pearls: Apixaban is SAFEST in renal impairment (only 27% renal clearance)
Dabigatran is most renally cleared - AVOID in CrCl <30
Rivaroxaban MUST be taken with food (improves absorption)
DOACs are INFERIOR to warfarin in APS - don't use
Reversal: idarucizumab for dabigatran; andexanet for Xa inhibitors
DOACs don't need bridging - short half-life
